benchmark_details.name: IOR-Bench (Intelligent Outpatient Referral Benchmark)
benchmark_details.overview: IOR-Bench provides a systematic framework for assessing the performance of models in outpatient referral scenarios through static and dynamic evaluation methods in the context of healthcare.
benchmark_details.data_type: static classification and dynamic dialogue data

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: The primary objective is to evaluate large language models' capabilities in outpatient referral tasks using a dual framework for static and dynamic evaluations.

data.source: The IOR dataset comprises real patient interactions sourced from hospitals in China, with careful ethical considerations and privacy compliance during data collection.
data.annotation: Data was manually annotated by medical professionals following strict guidelines, ensuring accuracy and compliance.

methodology.calculation: Accuracy is calculated by comparing the predicted department to the ground truth annotated by medical professionals.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better model performance in correctly directing patients to the appropriate departments during outpatient referrals.
methodology.baseline_results: BERT-Base-Chinese achieved an accuracy of 76.00% in static evaluation tasks, with human doctors achieving up to 87.24%.
methodology.validation: The framework has been validated through both automated methods and human evaluations with participating medical staff.

targeted_risks.demographic_analysis: The benchmark allows for demographic breakdowns based on patient data within the dataset.
harm: Misleading medical recommendations due to inaccurate model predictions.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: All patient data has been anonymized and de-identified to protect privacy.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.consent_procedures: The study received ethical approval from the relevant committees before conducting data collection.
